p: Accounting for 8 % of the human genetic material, human endogenous retroviruses (HERVs) represent a footprint of ancestral germ-cell infections in which viruses integrated into the host genome and were transmitted in a Mendelian form to the progeny [ 4]. Structurally, HERVs retain all retroviral hallmarks, including the gal, pol & env genes flanked by non-coding long terminal repeats (LTRs). Although most HERVs have lost the capacity of horizontal transmission due to gene defects, some have retained this ability despite their apparent apathogenicity [ 5– 7]. To ensure proliferation, they sequestrate intact elements from co-expressed exoviruses to form functional entities [ 8– 10].
